algorithms.sort

Class MiscSorter

  • java.lang.Object
    • algorithms.sort.MiscSorter

  • public class MiscSorter
extends java.lang.Object
    first implemented in project https://github.com/nking/curvature-scale-space-corners-and-transformations w/ Copyright (c) 2014 Climb With Your Feet and using The MIT License (MIT) then moved to this shared library project which has the same copyright and license. NOTE: for a more efficient version of merge-sort that uses an auxiliary array to hold intermediate partial sorting, and uses insertion sort for the shortest segments in the divide and conquer pattern, see algorithms.correlation.UnivariateDistance._sortCheck().
    Author:
    nichole

                                         double[] a2)
        use merge sort to sort a1 and a2 by a1 in ascending order, breaking ties by a2 and return the indexes of the original indexes (i.e. 0 through a1.length-1) in the sorted order.
        Parameters:

      • sortBy1stArg

        public static void sortBy1stArg(int[] a,
                                int[] b)
        use quicksort to sort a by ascending values and perform the same operations on b. Uses the optimized qsort3 from the book "Programming in Pearls" by Jon Bentley.
        Parameters:
        a -
        b -

      • sortBy1stArgThen2nd

        public static void sortBy1stArgThen2nd(float[] a1,
                                       float[] a2)
        sort by increasing value a1 and apply same changes to a2. Ties are further sorted by increasing values of a2. runtime is O(N * log_2(N))
        Parameters:
        a1 - array of points to be sorted
        a2 - array of points to apply a1 sorting to also

      • sortBy1stArgThen2nd

        Parameters:

        a2 - array of points to apply a1 sorting to also

        idxHi - stopping index of sorting of a1, inclusive

        use quicksort to sort a from index idxLo to idxHi, inclusive, by ascending values and perform the same operations on b. Uses the optimized qsort3 from the book "Programming in Pearls" by Jon Bentley.

        b -

        use mergesort to sort by decreasing value a1 and apply same changes to a2. Ties are further sorted by increasing values of a2. runtime is O(N * log_2(N))

        a1 - array of points to be sorted
        a2 - array of points to apply a1 sorting to also

      • sortByDecr

        public static void sortByDecr(int[] a1,
                              int[] a2,
                              int idxLo,
                              int idxHi)
        use mergesort to sort by decreasing value a1 and apply same changes to a2. Ties are further sorted by increasing values of a2. runtime is O(N * log_2(N))
        Parameters:
        a1 - array of points to be sorted
        a2 - array of points to apply a1 sorting to also
        idxLo - smallest index to participate in sort
        idxHi - largest index to participate n sort

      • sortByDecr

                              int[] a2,

                              int idxHi)
        use mergesort to sort by decreasing value a1 and apply same changes to a2. Ties are further sorted by increasing values of a2. runtime is O(N * log_2(N))
        Parameters:

        a2 - array of points to apply a1 sorting to also

        idxHi - largest index to participate n sort

      • sortBy1stArgThen2nd

        public static void sortBy1stArgThen2nd(int[] a1,
                                       int[] a2)
        sort by increasing value a1 for ties sort by a2. Ties are further sorted by increasing values of a2. runtime is O(N * log_2(N))
        Parameters:
        a1 - array of points to be sorted
        a2 - array of points to apply a1 sorting to also

      • sortBy1stArgThen2nd

        public static void sortBy1stArgThen2nd(int[] a1,
                                       int[] a2,
                                       int[] a3)
        sort by increasing value a1 for ties sort by a2. Ties are further sorted by increasing values of a2. runtime is O(N * log_2(N))
        Parameters:
        a1 - array of points to be sorted
        a2 - array of points to apply a1 sorting to also
        a3 - array of points sorted by same order as a1 and a2, useful to pass in the original index ordering for example.

      • sortBy1stArgThen2nd

        public static void sortBy1stArgThen2nd(int[] a1,
                                       int[] a2,
                                       int idxLo,
                                       int idxHi)

        a2 - array of points to apply a1 sorting to also
        idxLo - starting index of sorting of a1, inclusive
        idxHi - stopping index of sorting of a1, inclusive

      • sortBy1stArgThen2nd

        public static void sortBy1stArgThen2nd(int[] a1,
                                       int[] a2,
                                       int[] a3,
                                       int idxLo,
                                       int idxHi)
        Parameters:
        a1 - array of points to be sorted
        a2 - array of points to apply a1 sorting to also and act as tie breaker
        a3 - array of points sorted by same order as a1 and a2, useful to pass in the original index ordering for example.
        idxLo - starting index of sorting of a1, inclusive
        idxHi - stopping index of sorting of a1, inclusive
